awd_titl_txt: Conference: Ecology and Evolution of Infectious Diseases 2023: Celebrating Successes and Challenging Conventions
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will fund a workshop for graduate students and post-doctoral scholars on “Communicating Novelty and Controversy in the Ecology and Evolution of Infectious Diseases.” The workshop will be held in conjunction with the annual EEID meeting at Pennsylvania State University in May 2023. The experience of the COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need to develop strong relationships and trust between the research community and these various constituencies before a crisis. The workshop will be organized around 3 sessions: 1) case studies of innovation and misinformation in focal pathogens and “gain of function” research, 2) communicating novelty and risk, 3) tailoring communication to different audiences. It will focus on skills and strategies for communicating infectious disease science effectively to varied audiences and settings using the trainees own research. Doing so will develop individual skills in communicating science and formalize training in science communication, which can become standard practice for future cohorts. The workshop will train 30 early-career scientists in effective communication to broad audiences including lay public, agency, and policy-makers. Participants will represent a wide diversity of backgrounds, including students and post-doctoral scholars from groups underrepresented in STEM. The workshop will provide an opportunity for networking among junior researchers, particularly those from institutions with limited EEID research programs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Between 20-22 May 2023, we held a workshop on Communicating Novelty and Controversy in the Ecology and Evolution of Infectious Disease (EEID) for 31 participants. Participants included graduate students and post-doctoral scholars from programs in the US, UK, Kenya, Australia, and Singapore. Over 3 days the participants developed skills in the communication of novel and controversial results in EEID for scientific, policy, and lay audiences. The program included active learning components in which the participants worked individually and in groups to develop, and critique, summary presentations of their research projects for various audiences. This was facilitated by 1 day of content led by facilitators from the Alan Alda Center for Communicating Science that centered around templates for constructing messages and approaches for empathizing and connecting with audiences to tailor presentations. Lecture-based content included presentations from leading researchers in the EEID field about their experiences in communicating controversial topics including vaccine hesitancy and the fast-paced updating of epidemiological information during the COVID-19 pandemic, as well as formal theory on the communication of uncertainty and risk. 

Presenters included 

- Dr. Seth Bordenstein on the challenges of communicating novel scientific information about microbiome science against a socio-cultural backdrop where with a high volume of weakly or unsupported popular culture information about the microbiome.

- Drs. Nita Bharti and Andrew Read on the challenges of communicating risk and benefit in gain-of-function research in infectious disease biology.

- Dr. Matthew Ferrari on targeting messages for health policy organizations based on his experiences with national and international health NGOs. 

- Dr. Lewis Bartlett on his experiences developing content and building trust with public and industry groups in the context of pollinator science

- Dr. Carl Bergstrom on his experiences refuting and challenging the spread of mis-information on social media about COVID-19 on platforms

- Dr. Shannon Cruz presented a capstone presentation on communications theory  with specific focus on the limitations of the deficit model and strategies for audience segmentation and persuasion. 

 

In addition to this workshop, the participants were supported to attend the 20th Anniversary EEID Conference from 22-25 May. This conference included presentations organized into 4 oral sessions on the subjects of transmission, within-host dynamics, persistence, and diversity and heterogeneity.
